reviewText:
I'm not much of a reviewer, but after reading the response to Trine 3 I felt I should also put in my two cents. Because I really liked Trine 3. Despite being very different from the previous games in the series, Trine 3 still has the beauty and the soul I came to know and love. The gameplay has changed (pretty drastically), but that is not necessarily a bad thing. This is what I thought was positive, neutral, and negative;

The positive:

- The storytelling. Now, it is true that the story in Trine 3 has an open ending (which I agree with other reviewers is a negative point). However, the part of the story that is told is told magnificently. The story of Trine 3 tackles the origin of the Trine and the other artifacts of power. Personally, I was completely engaged by the story, much more so than I was by the stories of Trine and Trine 2. I really hope there will be another game to finish the tale.
- Visuals. The Trine games are all beautiful, this one being no exception. Everything is as colorful and fairytaleish as ever. I particularly loved the extra detail poured into the appearance of the three heroes. With each installment they've become more recognizable, which I consider a big plus. The first Trine was about a Thief, a Wizard and a Knight. Trine 3 is about Zoya, Amadeus and Pontius. Also, one level (I believe level 6) takes places within the pages of a book - rarely have I seen any part of a game that beautiful. Wow.
- The music. There's really not much to say about this; it's amazing. The soundtrack was made by the same person who made the soundtracks of Trine and Trine 2, and he has yet again failed to disappoint.
- The single character levels. In the main storyline levels of Trine 3, you can play as all three characters, just like in the previous games. However, Trine 3 also features plenty of non-story levels in which you only control one character. There are a few level focusing only on combat (most of which you play as Pontius, but also one as Amadeus) and each character has two mini-levels focused around that character alone. Pontius was separated from his companions, and his two levels focus on him getting back to them. Zoya's levels detail her search for the giant emerald she was chasing at the beginning of the game, and Amadeus takes a nap and goes on a quest for the elusive fireball spell in his dreams. I thought these levels were really quirky and fun.

The neutral:

- The 3D. On one hand, it is a refreshing change from the first two Trine games. The extra dimension really adds to the puzzle aspects of the game, opening a whole new dimension (literally) of possibilities. On the other hand, the camera sometimes acts wonky and missing a platform and dying is very easy. The 3D is great for the puzzles, less great for the platforming.
- The character's abilities. Like many other reviewers, I was sad to see the variety of hero-specific tools and powers diminished. Zoya no longer has any special arrows, Pontius has lost his hammer, and Amadeus can now only conjure one box at a time. However, there are some new abilities I really came to like. Zoya's rope (grappling hook) has become much more advanced. She can now tie both ends of the rope to two different objects, which is very helpful for solving puzzles. And, my favorite change, Amadeus is now actually useful in battle. I had tons of fun smashing boxes down on enemies, and he was actually my go-to combat character this time around.
- Having to collect Trineangles (which were experience bottles in Trine and Trine 2) to unlock levels. As a collector and achievement hunter, I never even move on to another level until I'm sure I've collected everything in the previous level, but I can imagine other players being frustrated by this. If you do not have enough Trineangles to unlock the next level, you will have to replay a previous level to collect more. The Trineangles, however, are a lot less hard to find than experience bottles, so it should not take too long to collect enough.
- There are a few minor bugs. Zoya glitches a bit when she has her bow drawn, sometimes you can phase though part of a wall, that sort of thing. I found nothing game-breaking, however, and the little bugs I found did not keep me from enjoying the game. I have read that there were some issues with multiplayer, but having only played solo, I cannot comment on them. Single player works like a charm, at least.

The negative:

- The lack of challenge. In the first Trine game, there were a few achievements that took some extra effort, like getting through a level without taking any damage. Trine 2 was achievement galore, and I spent many hours chasing the final hard and frustrating, but satisfying achievements. Trine 3, however, is already a fairly easy game, and there are no achievements which require you to do anything particularly special - just complete the game and collect everything. I finished the game (and collected all achievements) in about 7.5 hours. Compared to Trine 2 (40 hours) and even the first Trine (13.5 hours), that is very little time. This is not because the game itself is too much shorter than the first two games, but because there is no extra challenge. I would have loved to see some achievements requiring you to finish the game on a hard difficulty, or even some of the wacky achievements from the first two games that force you to go out of your way to do silly things like making an enemy sail on an improvised raft.
- The ending. It's been said by many others, and I can only confirm it. The game ends in the middle of the story, which makes it seem unfinished. From the forum I've understood that the developers planned on this from the beginning, but failed to inform their fans. Now, I did not buy Trine 3 immediately after its release, so I had time to read the reviews before purchasing the game and I knew what to expect from the ending. However, I can imagine that those who did buy the game right off the bat were bitterly disappointed by the lack of proper ending. So, if you want to buy Trine 3, do be noted that the ending is completely open and the fate of the heroes is left ambiguous.
- There is no leveling. While I was neutral on the characters' abilities being mixed up, I was disappointed by the fact that all abilities are unlocked for every character from the start. The reward of unlocking extra powers for characters (rather than the much more tedious task of having to collect things to unlock levels) is, I think, what made many players chase collectibles happily. Now the collecting has become a chore, as the awesome reward of new abilities has been replaced by the unlocking of levels - which I believe we are already entitled to, as we bought the game, and therefore doesn't feel like a reward at all.

So, in conclusion, Trine 3 is indeed very different from Trine and Trine 2, and fans of the previous games are not by default guaranteed to like this one. However, in my opinion, different is not the same as worse in this case. Trine 3 is still a beautiful, quirky game with a lovely story, great characters and wonderful music. As long as you're aware that Trine 3 is not like its predecessors, the game is very enjoyable. I hope FrozenBite will be able to make another addition to the series to give us a satisfying conclusion to the heroes' journey.

reviewText: Even though Trine 3:The Artifacts Of Power is shorter than Trine and Trine 2,the game finally delivers what i imagend a few years before,seeing those beautifully crafted backgrounds in trine 2 I just wanted to escape that linear path and explore everything,well now I can explore all of it(mostly).The implementation of 3D sure brings the feeling that you're better connected to the world,but the shortness of it can make you sad.Graphics are stunning,never thought the opposite in a Trine game.Controls are quite good and responsive,but certainly more complex than in previous installments.The lack of skills doesn't bother me that much really,yes it was a fun way to solve puzzles in the previous Trines,but the heroes were so overpowered(especially Zoya) that the other two weren,t needed in most cases.Pontius was usually useless when i played with other people,I used Amadeus for trolling :D,Zoya just flew through the level with her graplling hook.To be honest, i mostly miss the items from Trine 1,God,the feeling of a sidescroller RPG,best thing ever.Now,I think,everything is balanced.Finally a thing I most enjoyed in Trine 3-Story acctually made sense.Trine 1 was darker,In my opinion,Trine 2 was brilliant,but the story was forgettable,Trine 3,on the other hand,finally brings a story worth telling,how it all came to be,what is Trine acctually?Questions I've asked myself forever.Story,however,was never the main focus of Trine,it was gameplay,visuals and mayhem with friends.It's shorter,but most certainly,it isn't a step backwards.Looking forward to Shadwen.If anything,buy this game on a sale,just to support the developers,they deserve it.It would be most sad not to see Trine 4.

reviewText:
Trine 3: The Artifacts of Power is worth buying if you were a fan of the previous installments, but it may be too shallow for you than previously so it'd be best to wait for a sale.

Even with the addition of 3D movement instead of 2D, the game feels much simpler/easier/narrower. Puzzles seem too basic and don't generally take too long to figure out, enemies in combat almost never touch you, and there are no items to find/equip and no extra skills to upgrade or unlock.

If you are looking at buying the game, it only has about 4 hours of content, and that is if you spend time collecting everything and doing all of the optional levels.

reviewText:
Trine 3 is overall, a fun, beautiful game. You don't have to play the first two to enjoy the third one. Also, local multiplayer is an option!

The upsides: The graphics are stunningly beautiful. The co-op works great, and the puzzles are well designed. Some of the bonus levels are quite challenging. The story is also interesting, and the dialog is witty; you'll smile and laugh often as the characters interact. A huge improvement over the previous installments is that the level select screen gives you hints as to where the missing collectable 'Trineangles' are in the levels. This really increased replayablility, and decreased frustration.

The downsides: Frozenbyte was only able to complete the first half of the game, so it ends abruptly at a cliffhanger. They did say they would produce the rest when they had enough in their budget to finish the game. Occasionally, the 3d is difficult to navigate, and occasionally there are bugs - every once in awhile the 'trineangles' would only collect for one person in multiplayer. This wasn't a major issue, more a minor annoyance.

Overall, I strongly recommend this game. It's tons of fun, with great multiplayer, and a beautiful world to explore.

reviewText:
Trine 1 was good.  Trine 2 was very good.  Trine 3 not so much.

The graphics/visuals are nice as usual however the 3D depth is screwed up.  Or should I say lack of depth perception.  Several times I jumped to my death, not because that was the plan but I had no reference so instead of jumping to the platform, I jump left/right of platform.

I think the devs would have been better off updating a few things but keep the core the same.  Tell a good story and make the game fun as you did in Trine 1 & 2.  I'm not even sure I want to spend more time playing this one.  At least I got it on sale.

reviewText:
A buggy, unfinished and disappointing mess. The dev team clearly ran out of budget at some point and/or bit more than they could chew.

The game looks pretty and shiny, but the style just doesn't work as well in a 3D plane; the environments, while breathtaking, feel messy, cramped, and I'm often left wondering what's in the foreground and what's in the background, leading me to misjudge the depth of a jump and die more times than I'd care to admit.

Level progression is completely non-existent in this installment, consequently, there's practically zero motivation to go around getting all the collectibles like there was in the previous games. Characters have been streamlined, retaining their basic starting skills but missing the extra abilities that made it possible and fun to improvise around the different puzzles that the game threw at you.

Perhaps the most disappointing aspect about this whole thing is the way they handled the story; the game ends right when the first act would usually wrap up in a traditional three act narrative. It comes out of nowhere, goes nowhere, and not much gets explained. Even as someone who didn't care much for how the plot panned out, it was very jarring to see.

Other complaints include horrible lip syncing (no seriously, their mouths would start moving literally 30 seconds before anything was said), ugly character models (Zoya looks like she's been tweaking out with her eyes bulging out all the time and Pontius' model is way too realistically modeled to fit the style), and way too many bugs to even begin to list (luckily, none have been game breaking for me). Ironically, the bugs are what made this enjoyable to play, so I don't know if more QA would've made this better or worse to go through. With two friends tagging along, it was hilarious to see all the ways this fell apart as we tried to cheese our way through the puzzles.

If you're looking at this and thinking about buying it, play Trine 1 and 2 first. If you have and want more, buy this one only if it's on sale and you have people to suffer through it with you.

reviewText:
God where do I start.

First off, game is gorgeous. Huge props to the folks that worked on the environments. But that's really the only praise I have.

Game is bugged to hell and back. There were several times where my friends and I had to cheese our way through puzzles because a block or ramp would glitch out of existance/get stuck/launch into space. It's extremely difficult to judge the depth of where you are, making some of the platforming needlessly frustrating. A lot of the fun skills have been removed, and collecting everything just seems like a waste of time. The game is too short and the story ends on a completely unsatisfying note. I wouldn't even call it a cliffhanger because it doesn't build itself up that much; it just stops like they didn't have time to finish.

If you like the series and it's on sale, buy it only if you're gonna be playing with friends. The co-op is honestly the only thing that changes the bugs from frustrating to hilarious.

reviewText: I just finished up Trine 3 and I definitely have a less favorable feeling about this one then the first 2. Like always, they did a great job with the look of the game. Could be rose colored glasses, but I thought the prior two had more variety in their puzzles. I'm not sure what group Trine 3 is trying to appeal to. The puzzles don't require much thought, you don't need real strong timing or twitch skills, and the story really isn't a reason to play.\n\nI guess maybe I answered my own question. This seems geared for a casual platformer player (which is fine). I liked the first 2 quite a bit, maybe because they were fresher to me. I didn't remember as much fighting in the first 2 and the fighting in Trine 3 was pretty bad. The controls for the wizard's levitate ability was awkward fairly often. I wouldn't really recommend this to anyone but players who don't look for much challenge.

reviewText:
Trine 3 tries to add something new to the gameplay that worked so well in Trine 1 and Trine 2.  They both succeeded and failed, but the game itself is still fun to play, though below the standard that the previous iterations offered.

They took away the upgrades that you could get for each of the magician, fighter and thief.  Now you the magician can only create one box at a time, the thief can use the grappling hook and arrows like before, and the fighter can charge and use his shield to block.  This simplifies the gameplay in comparison to the previous games, but it still doesn't take away from the fact the game is fun, especially in multiplayer.

The addition of a true 3D world where you can move left to right as well as into the depths of the gameplay add some interesting features and gameplay environments.  I read some reviews complaining about not being to tell the exact depth of the graphics, and I agree there were some issues about that, but none that I felt I couldn't learn and deal with properly and move on in the game.  The graphics were just as good if not better than the previous games and this is something that Frozenbyte is known for and they didn't fail at all.

The game is short and does end abruptly, at least compared to the previous games.  However, if I look at Trine 3 all on its own, I must recommend playing this game.  The simplicity of the multiplayer helps make the game smoother than Trine 2, but less challenging.  I would have preferred to see the challenge still there, but all in all I enjoyed playing the game.  Speaking of less of a challenge, you can notice this by looking at how easy the achievements are compared to the previous games.  I know it sounds like I'm saying many cons rather than the positives, but Trine 1 and Trine 2 were such stellar game experiences, that it's rough when you compare them.  However, as a stand alone game, the game is very enjoyable.

reviewText:
UPDATE TO REVIEW, SCROLL DOWN

According to the other reviews, the game is ♥♥♥♥, but most of them seemed to be focusing on the multi-player aspect. So for me I only have 2 hours at the time of this review, and that will grow until I complete the game, but in the singleplay I don't see any of the complaints that a lot of other people are having. So far I have ran into minimal glitches, and the puzzels are just as deep as in Trine 2. I also see the other people say the story ends abrudtly, which I have yet to figure out for myself, but so far the story, within only 2 hours has kept me interested. The graphics in this game as per usual are amazing, and playing on my crappy laptop, only on the very low settings it still looks stunning, with the normal enchanting Trine styled landscapes and colors bringing you to a very fantasy like place. The movement is this game is also very smooth. When I saw that they were moving away from the 2D platforming that they did in Trine 1 and 2, I was skeptical, first off because I didn't see a reason for them to change it, but when I hopped in and started playing, it still had the classic Trine feeling to me.

In short: According to others, the multiplayer is bad, but I have found the single player to be enjoyable

The story so far has been compelling and interesting

The graphics, and game design are great

Minimal bugs, (I have only ran into two which I'd say is pretty average, and they weren't game breaking or anything)

There is Smooth and enjoyable movment

Over all I think that this game doesn't deserve the bad stigma that many other people are giving it, so don't let other reviews throw you off too too much!

UPDATE:

As much as I wanted to like this game I can't give it a solid recommendation after completing it. Over all this game left me feeling super empty. So the game bassically is made of 3 different styles, one where you are at a wizard castle, in a book with very bland colors, a snowy forest and  a generic boss fight stage. The rest of the game is made up of a few side quests, that you MUST do to progress through the main story.

Now that isn't my main complaint. My problem is that there just isn't enough. The game leaves you off where it shouldn't and to me it looks likes the developers tried to get more rmoney by not making this a complete game. The game leaves of to set up a sequel where there shouldn't be one is what im basically saying. Now this annoys me a lot. The trine games normally have great story but then when you come to this game is very, and I mean very lack luster. It started out interesting and then it turned out to be a thrown togethor mess.

Now another problem I had with this game as comming back after finishing it is that it had Zoya as a very and I mean VERY usless character. She had no part in the boss level and in most other levels she was just a swing around little thing, which is a shame beacuse in Trine 2 she was a lot of fun to play with.

Now the last part that urked me is the lack of boss levels, and how the game lead into them. The game seemed to just throw them in as an after thought instead of actually making it flow through the game. In trine 2 you are walking through a forest and then you seemlesly walk into a boss that I didn't expect, but in this game you have to load a new level and it is very predictable if you have half a brain.

So with all of this in factor as well as the first review, I am going to be neutral on this game. I would only suggest buying it on a large sale or if you are a super mega fan and just can't keep your hands off this series. Although I can't actually not give a up or down so im going to just keep it as an up!

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Trine 3: The Artifacts of Power was released by Frozenbyte, late 2015. Common themes found in Trine games are: fantasy graphics and locations, story book tale telling, and puzzles.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: Once again our Hero's Zolya, Amadeus, and Pontius are brought together to assist the Trine (A magical Artifact the three hero's have gained power from) in yet another adventure. However, this time the Hero's are growing weary of always helping the Trine and they are starting to become quite discontent.
This results in the most uncalled for over reaction I've ever seen anyone have, let alone an animated object that look like a trophy-cup with a ball on it.

Game Play:
So what's different?
The biggest change in Trine 3: The Artifacts of Power, is that Trine3 is in 3D. By that, I mean the game is played in a 3D plane unlike the past games which are played on a 2D plane and emulate classic side-scrolling gameplay, but with fancy fantasy graphics.
(My opinion: I'm double minded on how I feel about this game change; I both love it, and dislike it - I really love the classic 2D Trine... but I adjusted to the 3D change quite quickly. However, there are many inevitable deaths because it's difficult trying to tell where  a floating block is without a shadow. I could forgive these deaths because there's barely any consequence from dying.)

reviewText:
God, this must be how Star Wars fans felt when Episode 1 came out, incredible improved graphics and a rich detailed world stripped of most of its fun and charm. Like so many of us, I loved Trine, and when Trine 2 came out it brought improved graphics, a longer main gameplay and story and some fantastic multiplayer/co-op additions which all added to the original formula and gave more value to me. So why oh why would you want to throw all your money at the styling and art only to ditch the core values that made the first two games so successful Frozenbyte? Yes, the 3D is an interesting addition and the graphical improvements and design have not gone unnoticed, but when they result in emptying out all the challenge, cutting the playtime in half and doubling the price, you have know you're making a bad choice somewhere in development.

Highlights
It feels as though the majority of Trine 3s' development has been focused around the new 3D Engine and the graphical artefacts and objects therein and at least to a small degree, it's paid off. It's fantastic to traverse a world where the same intricate level of detail from the first two games has remained, and due to the textures, resolutions, and most of all the lighting effects, the world and environments look even better. There's been a lot of time and effort spent on making most of the objects and art interactable or responsive in some way, and the world (though probably not the story and characters) truly feels a little more immersive than in the prior 2 titles.

The other thing that I really liked was the side objectives, though I felt due to the short length of the game they'd been forced into main content (you actively need to complete them to progress with the story now) which is a shame, but doesn't stop them from being great side-stories and fun in their own ways. They even have jokes and references to other games and they helped break up some of the issues the game has.

Mistakes and Annoyances
The single biggest player complaint on this title is the short length and/or the unfinished story/abrupt ending. While I felt the levels themselves were too short, there were more than enough of them to make up a full game here and it honestly doesn't feel that much shorter than the first title, especially considering the love and attention that has been put into making them so beautiful to look at, I think we've just been spoiled from the length and amount of content put into the second title. However, as Frozenbyte have confirmed, they simply ran out of funding and released what they had with a rather short, flat and emotionless ending, which truly is a shame when the happy comradery and whimsicle story were the fun backdrop upon the last two titles shone. Ultimately the gameplay and game itself are what count most and the ending with the comparatively short 5 hour play-time aren't what bother me most since 5 hours of a good title is, in my experience, worth more than 10 hours of a less enjoyable title. Instead it's the other failings and choices that make me very concerned and cautious about recommending Trine 3 and so ultimately the price is my single biggest complaint. Twice the price of the other titles when it's the least challenging, least engaging and most buggy of the three is simply an outright joke.

The 3D Engine is the cause of a few of those problems, particularly the lack of precision and accuracy seen in the prior two games. It a regular thing to jump past an area or over a platform only to fall or die because the controls or leap felt impinged by the engine, and even more annoying when it happens because you can't see what's around the corner. This has clearly been addressed somewhat by removing some of the challenge and slowing down the game a little, which I would normally be fine with, but when it's overdone so far as that it makes the entire game unchallenging, removes the progression system where you can unlock new skills and abilities and simply replaces them with collectibles, it feels cheap, flat, bland and worst of all, boring.

Recommendations
Currently available on the Steam store for £31.99/44.99€/$44.99, Trine 3 is flat out overpriced. It's not a bad game, and while it lacks the challenge, complexity and some of the fun of the first two, it definitely still has a great world and environment to explore if you keep your expectations on level, but given the lack of improvement and the large price it just isn't worth the cost for most of us. If you want to pick it up, do yourself a favour and wait until it's less than the price you got the prior two titles, as that's the only price at which I'm comfortable recommending it to most, especially when you take into account that the developer have mentioned the story and game will not be updated or extended in the future.

At the time of writing this title is also available in the Trinology which is incredible value, especially on sale, and the Frozenbyte Collection 2015 which includes the whole of the Trinology and the two Shadowgrounds titles for an extra buck and change. As always, Trine 3 has a good multi-pack option and you can save another buck or two if you find friends to split with.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/319910/

Unedited review notes 25/11/2015 for Trine 3: The Artifacts of Power:

-Price is enormous, more than 2 times the cost of the original game, so it'd better be twice as good
-It isn't twice as good
-It's considerably worse
+3D is genuinely fun to play with. Stopping and exploring adds a bit of time and fun to the ultra short levels
-3D removes the precision and speed that are required to make this a challenging puzzle platformer and adds frustrations
+Interacting with more on screen elements is a small thing but neat
+Level select map screen doesn't add much but is nice and more story immersive which is a plus and slightly missing from the prior 2 titles
-Levels are far too short, just when you get into a rhythm you get pulled out
-+Characters/story/writing/humour aren't as good as the previous titles, though arguably it's only marginally lesser than the second title
-Not challenging whatsoever. This was a problem in Trine 2 but not nearly as bad as it is here.
-Many puzzles aren't obvious and can't be worked out other than by chance of messing around with everything on screen. I accidentally" solved a few puzzles without having any clue what I was supposed to actually do.
-Small annoyances like no artefact count per level
date: so if you've missed an artefact you'll need to replay the entire section
recommended: but it doesn't tell you once you've completed a section either

reviewText: For a series I have loved so much that continues to be so visually beautiful, Trine 3 is regrettably such an awful shame. The awkward controls because of the fixed-camera 3D and annoying client replication issues in multiplayer make me quit every time I have sat down to try and play it.\n\nI really hope that new games in this franchise return to the style of Trine and Trine 2. It's not worth forcing 3D into a game if it is done poorly, and things like Zoya's bow and Amadeus's telekenesis just don't translate well.

reviewText:
I'm a fan of Trine and Trine 2, but I simply couldn't even finish this one. The controls are not good and feel like a struggle. You have no control over the camera so it's sometimes hard to judge how deep a platform is, I managed to miss a platform over 5 times because I just couldn't tell how far from the camera it was. No more skills. You collect 'pyramids' throughout the game, which unlock new levels. So I got in a position where to play the next level I either had to finish several challenges that I didn't like because of the controls, or replay previous levels to collect more pyramids. I'd much prefer a shorter game that would allow me to play all levels one after another over padding it out with this kind of system. That's why I didn't even finish the game.
To its defense, tha graphics are incredibly nice and recognizable as a Trine game. Also, when you want to replay a level to collect more pyramids, you can choose from any sub-parts that even tell you how much stuff in them you've collected.
I'm really sad about this game. Trine 1 and 2 wanted me to play more, and to press on when I got stuck, Trine 3 just makes me look for excuses not to launch it any more. 2 silver sloths.

reviewText:
Trine 3 is a very gorgeous platforming game with dreamy faretale landscapes and music.
It's similar but nevertheless a stark depature from earlier Trine games. The added 3D layer changes gameplay quite a bit and the fixed camera makes it very hard to determine where you need to jump at times, resulting in many unnecessary deaths. Camera controls would help immensely and should definitely be in a game like this.
It is still enjoyable once you've gotten the hang of thing, but that can take a while  - and unfortunately the game is not very long. I completed it in about 6 hours, collecting everything and getting all achievements. The brevity wouldn't be an issue, but since the story is ending very abruptly and it wasn't known prior to release that Trine 3 would end in a cliffhanger, it's a bit disgruntling.

HOWEVER - Albeit these criticisms, the biggest being the fixed camera, I still recommend it if you like platformers, are okay with the price tag and don't mind cliffhanger endings. It's still a good game.

reviewText:
The puzzles are pretty easy compared to other platform games, but I enjoyed the scenery enough that I didn't mind. Attempting to avoid a spoiler, one section has simulated paper... It is inspired; I hope to see this again in the future.
I enjoyed the 3D environment. Despite being an 'on-a-rail' type of game, there is enough freedom to explore. You can take a break to look around and appreciate the view. You can't get the camera to show every location your player can reach, such as behind buildings, but there is nothing hidden there so it doesn't really matter. You can walk of cliffs and die. So try to avoid it (like in real life). One minor complaint is in multiplayer, when a player dies, the 'ghost' of the player sometimes levitates to a location ahead of the other players, so you might have to wait a bit before another player can reach your ghost to resurrect it.
You can map the commands to the buttons and keys of your choice, which I always appreciate since I don't use the standard WASD mapping.
Using PC keyboard and mice it took my group a few tries to defeat the end game boss. I think a controller would have been easier, especially for jumping in non-cardinal directions. But even one younger player who is typically easily frustrated, didn't even think of giving up. I expect we will replay this again, like we did Trine 1 and 2.

Note to Frozenbyte: You can't please everybody. You took a risk to go to 3D. You learned from it. I hope you don't give up on 3D because I enjoy it and I think you did it right. I bought three copies at full price and we weren't disappointed. If you try again with Kickstarter, I'll be there. Hopefully you'll get enough cash to work out more bugs and avoid some of the negative reviews. Some people complained they didn't like some of the voice acting. After listening to some poor English overdubs of Anime, I had no problems at all with your voice cast.

reviewText:
Genre: 3D Platformer/Puzzle/Adventure
First of all, yes this is an unfinished game. Devs were short on money, so they just decided to cut the game in the middle of the story. I didn't care for a story in first Trine even though I am a story guy, however in this game the story was intriguing, but sadly it will stay unfinished. But, I still think that this is a good game, and I enjoyed this more than first Trine at least(didn't play second yet). 3D is way more interesting in my opinion. In this game like before  you control 3 characters. Wizard, knight and archer. Every one of them has 2 abilities. Platforming is pretty fun, but the combat is meh. Puzzles in this game like in previous games are mostly easy, however there were 1-2 that were kinda hard. There are no any skill upgrades in this game(there were in first 2 games, but it's a bit rushed game, however I didn't mind this). Controls are fine even though some people complain, and I didn't encounter any bugs. Even though the game is rushed, fortunately it's very good otpimized like all games in the series. Graphic wise is more stunning than the first 2 games, and maybe the most beautiful game I've played so far. And like previous Trine games it also has a great atmosphere and the music. Game is about 5-7 hours long. It personally took me 7 hours to beat the game and get all achievements, since I needed to replay some levels so I can get all collectibles which are required so you can progress to the next level(you don't need them all at the beginning, but at the end for last few levels you will). Basically if you finish this game you're going to have at least 23-24 of 28 achievements that the game have.

Verdict: Nice platforming, beautiful visuals, mediocre combat, great atmosphere and the music. Well optimized. Shorter than first 2 Trine games, but in 3D which I found better for this series at least. There are no more skill upgrades, and the game's story is unfinished. I don't think that this is worth the full price, but it's definitely worth getting with 75-80%+ discount.

Personal rating: 7.5/10

reviewText:
As a big fan of the Trine series this game did not disappoint. Great level design, beatiful graphics and music. The big change from the Trine/Trine 2 was the 3D and changed abilities of all characters. Thieves hook is very often used in puzzles to connect certain objects. Wizards planks were removed and now he can only have 1 box at once but he has something like a slam ability with his boxes. They changed the knights melee combat animation but it's the same LMB spamming thing like before but it looks like he parries an enemy attack and then hits them instead of just swinging wildly. The ledge-grab" mechanic has been changed from spamming the jump key near a ledge to just holding it down. Level design is just awesome and a new sense of exploration because of the 3D. I haven't tried the co-op yet ( I have no friends who play Trine III :-C ). I highly recommend buying this game if you liked Trine and Trine 2.
And I'll add that this game has AWESOME game developers. They answer to all the questions on the forums pretty much in the 12-24 hours and keep the community in the loop and the steam workshop is awesmoe.

10/10

AFTER RELEASE

Well I was hoping there were more levels
date: but no matter. The best thing they added is when you restart a level ( to get the rest of the collectables that you didn't get ) you can select a part of the level. That's huge. They added more challenge levels that are challenging at first but after you beat them once you can pretty much do them eyes closed. I was expecting more levels but whatever. I'm sure there will be Trine 4 or DLC.\n\nP.S. I would recommend playing Trine I

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe 3D engine is done beautifully keeping with the series tradition of an orthographic-like camera yet allowing the player full x, y, and z navigation. Although only in early access the game already shows the promising polish of a great game in the making that is true to its predecessors in its fairy tale story telling of a magical whimsical setting and the characters are as lovable as ever. Trine 3: The Artifacts of Power does all the previous games justice with its respectful retention of the iconic art style and the amazing composer Ari Pulkkinen. This sequel is new and fresh with the new 3D features are innovative and welcome yet keeps what made the originals amazing.

reviewText: Just finished playing through Trine 3. I've put off purchasing this due to the many helpful" nagative reviews. However

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With the same taste and art they had crafted in the first two, Trine comes through for me with a 3rd installment of this wonderfully puzzling and magical series.

The graphics are just beautiful, the storyline is charming, the gameplay is just as challenging as it was before, only now the puzzles become even more dastardly as you fit into the 3D realm.

If you are a fan of platform puzzle games, you CAN NOT miss this title. You will live your life in shame if you do not try this series out. WOW... I am so impressed by this company and what they are doing. It is a turning point to me, and I was around when Castlvania 1 came out for the NES.

I should mention though, due to the early access stage that it is currently in, it is pretty short. Only abour 3 hours of gameplay, so if you aren't interested in supporting the series, I would wait until launch.

reviewText:
I just complete the entire game. As you can see, by my hours played. It doesn't take that long.. I played trine 2 and loved it. Always playing 3 man co-op, as did I this time. There is so much wrong with this game I'll try to put it all down, but I'm not sure I'll remember everything.

1. Very short gameplay, looks like there will be DLC's to complete the game, as it is clearly incomplete judging by the story line.
2. Zonya is competely useless. There are barely any things you can slingshot on. The mechanic feels clunky, and in comparison to Trine 2, hard to use and unrewarding. Zonya is the pontius of Trine 2, needs help at a lot puzzles, and when she doesn't she can just swing over with 0 problems just skipping everything. No explosive arrows. No freeze arrows. No invisibilty.
3. Pontius is overpowered. Why, because his attacks our so fast he stun locks everything while murdering it fast. He can spam his ground stomp, stunlocking everything and making everyones screen shake uncontrolably (NOTE: Screen shake can NOT be turned off). And the most OP thing about Pontius is that he can go up any vertical wall. By spamming jump and glide, you can steadily move up anything that has a wall connected to it. No magnetism.
4. Pontius doesn't even come close to the crazy OPness off the Mage. The mage can now walk while levitating his box. Meaning he can jump on the box, jump again, grab the floating box again and move it under his feet, jump again, etc. Also, pontius needed at least 1 wall, the mage can doesn't. He can launch himself up high in the air out of the screen, by simply standing on his boxes, jumping, and dragging the box fast upwards against himself. If there's nothing stopping you, can simply fly or reach anything with your 1 box. Can no longer spawn planks. No longer summons by making a box or plank shape (In my opion an very cool mechanic. Now deleted.)  no magnetism
This is not a bug by the looks of it, as you can now only spawn 1 box.
5. They deleted the skill tree. Yes, the fun progression you got by collecting those orbs in Trine 2, and slowly earning your new skills. Gone. You start of with the same abilities you end with. Nothing new. Actualy less then Trine 2.
6. Game is still full of bugs. Happended multiple times bridges start spazzing all over the place and disapearing. Falling through bridges or platforms. Teleporting after being hit by Mage box. Rope spazzes from Zonya. And lots and lots more.
7. 3D sucks balls. This game isn't meant for it. Clearly isn't. And judging by the game, it feels like the developers agree and just released the game, so they would be done with it and can focus on Trine 4. You have barely any concept of perception, you tend to jump infront or behind platforms half of the time. The mouse scrolling to change the depth of your floating box as a mage feels bad. It makes the game look less beautiful then in 2D.
8. The game is incomplete, and will most likely force you to by DLC's to complete the game. Which is just sponging us off for money, and that's all this game feels like right now.


TL;DR Game takes 3-4 hours to complete. You can cheese everything with pontius and the mage. Full of Bugs. Game is incomplete. Zonya is close to useless compared to the other 2. 3D is not the way to go for Trine.

I hope there will be a trine 4, as the first thing I'll do is replay Trine 2. I loved that game and still do, but this trash isn't worth a it's money, nor a second change for it's DLC. Please stop putting effort in this game and just start Trine 4 in 2D, so we can forget this ever happened.

reviewText: Tine 3 is quite some change to the predecessors, but I can still recommend it as a puzzle platformer. In single player it is very playable, Sure you will miss a few jumps misjudging distances, but that happened in 1 and 2 as well. The graphic style is beautiful.\n\nIn co-op you can still annoy each other, if you're not feeling like teamwork. The fighter can destroy the mages conjured boxes and cut the huntress's ropes. The mage can kill his unsuspecting friends moving objects inadvertently and conjure boxes in their faces, And the huntress can leave them all behind swinging from rope to rope. Unfortunately, co-op is also not working as intended. We had to reload several times to fix levels and puzzles we couldn't complete for some reason.

reviewText:
SHORT REVIEW:
+ graphics, soundtrack
+ 3D world/camera
+ individual character challenges
+ easy-to-learn character skills
+ use of physics
+ simple story
+ more ways to solve the problem
+ checkpoints/save system
+ focus on solving puzzle not on fights with enemies

- weak enemies
- slightly lower difficulty
- chapter map (points system)
- little to no graphics/visual options (unnecessary effects which can't be turned off)
- shorter gameplay: 1 or 2 more hours would be enough (longer than Trine 1, shorter than Trine 2)

LONG REVIEW:
I was worried after reading a lot of negative reviews but this game exceeded my expectations. It was an amazing experience, now, in 3D. During my gameplay I've experienced only 2 situations when I couldn't see my character which was fixed by moving a little or waiting for camera to reposition itself. Sometimes I couldn't hit the Trineangles because I wasn't sure where they exactly are in the 3D world but it took me only few attempts. Despite these facts I think the new 3D feature is really well-made and I didn't notice any serious problems with camera during my gameplay. First chapters are designed to learn you how to control your character and how to move within 3D world. The atmosphere is amazing. Graphics in the in the combination with soundtrack in the whole series is a masterpiece. There are a few new visual effects, new challenges where you have to use physics and a lot of ways how to solve problems. Terrible skill points system from Trine 2 is finally gone and possibilities for each one of the 3 characters are very clear, all 3 are needed. Individual challenges are something new because you have only one character (Amadeus/Pontius/Zoya) and you have to solve the problem without help from others. One thing I really didn't enjoy was chapter map (points system). I was missing 45 Trineangles so I had to play one big chapter again to collect more, also, I don't like if I need to choose which level I want to play, it should be clearly defined as progress in the story. Overall feeling from ~8 hours of gameplay is really great and I would recommend this game to every fan of the Trine series and also to every new player who likes Platformer/Indie genre.

reviewText:
Summary:The ending was a let down and it stopped short on a cliffhanger, but overall I thought this game was fun and fit into the Trine series well. The graphics are hands-down gorgeous and the world around you feels authentic and well crafted. The levels are decent, however the puzzles are a bit lacking in complexity compared to the previous Trine games. The music score is pleasant to listen to, but it's not as definitive Trine 2's soundtrack. The fights were fairly straight forward and easy, however they did throw in some pretty cool new enemies. If you try to get every collectable, you can complete this game in under 10 hours. As far as bugs go, it seems like they have patched most of them out at this point. The only bugs I found were mostly visual and non-gamebreaking. The only serious bug I encountered was a visual bug of ghost collectables following me around, which was fixed easily with a reload of an autosave.

Pros:Beautiful graphics
Well-crafted world
Very scenic with so many vibrant colors
Good story
Good voice actingNeutral:Decent music score
Mediocre puzzles
Fights are relatively easy
Controls can be a bit difficult to get used because of the 3D, although the camera did a good job ajusting for different angles.
Amadeus the Wizard can still make flying machines, but it's much harder now that he's limited to just one box and no platforms. However he can still fly with the combined powers of a spare box, Zoya's rope, and a little magicCons:Ends on a cliffhanger because the developer ran out of funding
Slighty buggy, but usually only when you are trying to break something
A lot of the old skills are gone, replaced by new ones that feel slightly underwhelming
Leveling up to gain new abilities isn't a thing anymore, you just have abilities from the start
A really lazy reference to Portal that they say twice in the same level for some unknown reasonOverall Score:7.7/10

reviewText:
3/5

If you enjoy the Trine series, you will enjoy the game, but Trine 3 doesn't quite meet all my expectations.

The biggest gripe about the game is that it is short - very, very short - and leaves the player feeling as though they have literally played 1/3 of a game, as the game ends at the 1/3 mark in the story. Very disappointing.

The first two games in the Trine series feel more challenging and the player feels rewarded, as there is some degree of character customization in that you are able to obtain trinkets and upgrade abilities. This aspect is completely absent from Trine 3 and is sorely missed, but what it lacks in challenge, it makes up for in beauty. In addition to the obvious graphics updates, Trine 3 upgrades the game series from 2D side-scroller to 3D side-scroller". This makes the gameplay more interesting

reviewText:
Trine 3: The Artifacts of Power is unfortunately quite the divisive title. This most recent addition to the Trine franchise attempts to breach new ground in terms of innovative gameplay, and while respectable in concept is flawed in implementation. Trine 3 can be described as a concept piece with a limited budget. It would seem that the visuals took the cake in regards to the budget, and in doing so failed to incorporate what makes the Trine franchise so enjoyable in it's previous iterations.

First of all the mechanics of the game received a complete downgrade, from the lackluster puzzles to the touchy combat, and the greatest offender - the platforming. Gone are the collectible items of Trine 1, gone are the unique skills of the three heroes in Trine 2. Each hero has been given one sole ability, from the Wizard's one box, to the Knights glide and the Thief's hook swing. This negates much of what made platforming such an enjoyable experience - the variety and complexity of how to traverse the terrain. In fact, the simplicity of movement was very important, and with the 3D" visuals one would need a sharper eye and the ability to perceive depth and distance more accurately.

Secondly
date: Trine 3 unfortunately manages to completely bypass any semblance of an original tracklist
recommended: and instead makes use of remixed music from both the previous titles. This is something that I can often look beyond
hoursPlayed: but as the previous Trine games have always delivered incredibly original
voteText: exceptional and beautiful music that I was saddened to see Trine 3 without it's own unique musical flair.\n\nThirdly
helpfulPercent: Trine 3 was surprisingly bereft of a story. It's narration was scattered
votesHelpful: and it's length incredibly short. The focus this time around was on the origins of the Trine
votesTotal: and throughout the narrative we gain little insight (if just slightly enough)
votesFunny: on the Trine
commentsCount: the other artifacts
column16: and our heroes antagonist - Sarek. Perhaps if the developers had taken this story to it's conclusion... perhaps if they had continued with another mission or two? Rebuild the Trine this game
column17: not the next. Give us a climax to the events of the game
column18: not a complete cutoff halfway through.\n\nNow
column19: perhaps the title's saving grace would be the fantastic visuals. The new "look" boasts some magnificient visuals and artwork as well as reasonably well designed and animated character and object models. Most importantly
column20: the absolutely stunning game level backdrops are quite the treat. Looking beyond the surface layer is where the gorgeous visuals truly shine. With Trine's attempt at 3D gameplay
column21: much was done to develop the world in terms of it's landscape
column22: from the rivers and oceans
column23: mountains and canyons
column24: castles and villages. Unique perspectives
column25: angles and the like really add to the overall achievement in artistic design and direction.\n\nIn the end
column26: Trine 3 is definitely a worthwhile casual product for those who truly love the Trine franchise. The dominant achievement would definitely be the excellent visuals
column27: but the lack of mechanics and narration should (and rightly so)
column28: drive off all newcomers. I recommend Trine 3: The Artifacts of Power

reviewText:
Trine 3 is the first in Trine series to be featuring a platformer in 3D. It's beautiful, as usual, and as to be expected from Frozenbytes. The scenery is breathtaking, and given that this is 3D makes it even better. And Soundtrack, of course, Akki really is a leading example how a composer should've been. Nothing less than magnificent. Soundtrack is included in Trine 3 folder as 192 kbps files (quite disappointing though they're not lossless, but better than nothing).

The next point... gameplay, unfortunately for gameplay... is very lacking. Game length is also very short. To be quite honest, despite the missing features, I still think it's a good game. The platformer essence is still there, although nerfed in many ways. In battle it's Pontius' chance here to shine, though, the other two are quite useless. Quite possibly this is major negative points that many players hate.

For Trine 4, I hope they can incorporate back the older features like tech trees/skills like before.

Still, I prefer to recommend the game, for me to give them negative would hurt the developer unnecessarily. I think they've heard the feedback from us playerbase loud enough, and they'll try to amend it. Remember how they treated older Trines and gave updates many times? Let's give them a chance.

Looking forward to Trine 4.

reviewText:
Amazing. Trine is truly a work of art. This is quality work and you can see it. A must try for all gamers. I'm currently at 300+ Triangles and will be completing the game. I will add more later on. Trine 3 suffers from the same problem as Trine 2, it's always too short. I finished the main campaign in 4 hours. Spoilers? Nah. Play the game to find out. Just note that there will be a Trine 4. Since the game ended too fast, pass for Frozenbyte.

$5.50 on the Steam Lunar New Year Sale.

PROS
1. Graphics
The beauty of the world of Trine is amazing. I've played Trine 2 and it still amazes me.

2. Foreground and Background
In and out, back and forth and even sideways. The variety of movement just allows for a great gameplay. While not fully 3D (which is not a problem at all), it gives players a change in environment that is fun to experience. You can see this in game like Little Red Riding Hood : Wolf, it's very interesting.

3. Warrior Buff
Luckily, there are some challenges that Pontius the Brave (The Warrior) is required to do. E.g. Reflecting fireballs with his shield

4. The Chapter Selection Board Game
So cool. I loved the way the developers set up the world on a board game with giant dice and multiple pieces.

5. Boss Fight
Pretty cool. I loved how the animated root is both a puzzle and a battle. E.g. Shooting his weak spot, followed by a attacking his heart

6. Picture Book Puzzle
Sure, it's just a skin change of the game. But it's refreshing to play.

7. Wizard's Tower
It's pretty well done. So far, this is the part that is most interesting.

8. Kippo
I love the giant troll? fisherman. I haven't caught a fish all day." The way he walks off into the background is just so enthralling.

CONS
1. OP Wizard
Still suffers from Amadeus being critical in certain puzzles. The ability to create crates is just necessary to give you that extra boost.

2. Weakest Warrior
Too many of his abilities are combat based and >50% of the game is puzzle based. Swinging the sword can be achieved by smashing heavy objects or arrows. He is useful for combat but the Thief can do the job as well. Perhaps more floating shield challenges or something only he can do underwater.

3. Foreground Death
I actually died jumping into the Foreground. Considering that you can't change the camera view
date:
this is very bad game design.

4. Too Short
4 hours and it's over? Fail. This is too short a game to be worth the money. I was secretly hoping you were going to surprise me with the cloud around the game board disappearing and showing me a gigantic map
recommended:
making me feel like the first 9 levels were just the tutorial.

SUGGESTIONS
1. Bending Light Puzzle
Pontius has a shiny shield
hoursPlayed:
right? How about bending light to hit key objects by reflecting them off his shield?

2. Spike Rain Puzzle
Hail of arrows. Only solvable by Pontius. Ensure that Amadeus' crate will break under the hailstorm of arrows. This will ensure that Pontius is given more importance.

3. Expandable Map
I wanted to see the clouds disappear and see an enormous map of the world of Trine with the mountains

reviewText:
Trine 1 was great. Trine 2 was a masterpiece, Trine 3 is awesome in every single way except the obvious abrupt ending. The gameplay is fun and funny at the same time as you take our familiar trio through a variety of physics based puzzles on a magical quest through a dreamy fantasy world that never looked better! I really can't stress enough how beautiful this game looks and no screenshot does it justice.

Unfortunately, the story really ends just when you actually make some progress on finding the artefact shards. It's obvious the team was either cut back or ran out of money for further development.

Regardless - I can strongly recommend the game since it's really loads of fun and TONS of beautiful eyecandy.

reviewText:
I usually write reviews after being done with a game, but I feel I should leave some early impressions already because I see so many negative reviews, especially about the controls. I'll edit my review when I'm done with the game.

Personally I think they did a fantastic job with the controls and puzzles. the added depth (literally) to the gameplay allows much more room to play around and find creative solutions.

About the lack of skill upgrades: People forget that Trine 2, with its skill upgrades, was already a simplified version of Trine 1 with its additional skills and also items and trinkets that you equip for buffs and so on. Each sequel is simplifying, and that's not necessarily bad because it's a lateral change, not a step down.

I have not played long enough to see if the idea of unlocking levels with gems is frustrating. In the early game it isn't, but maybe later it will be. I already like to replay levels, so I doubt this will bother me.

Probably the only thing that will really bother me is the reportedly short length of the game.

Overall, so far, I am loving it. So far, a worthy successor to the earlier games.
(And Lord, those graphics.)

reviewText:
Trine 3 is a decent game. Not an amazing game like the previous titles in the series, but solid nevertheless.

The visuals are great - the game further improves upon the style used in previous installations, and the now-varying camera angle permits for even prettier views.

Gameplay is OK - on one hand, the hero abilities differ from Trine 1/2, but there seems sense to that:
- The Thief's hook is replaced by a rope that clings onto specific movable and immovable objects. While this grants less movement freedom than the hook, aiming hook at arbitrary surfaces with a third-person camera would undoubtedly be a complete mess, and the rope is given it's own features (tying objects together and/or tying around corners and objects).
- The Wizard only summons boxes now. A bit of a shame, of course, but then, summoning planks would imply rotating planks, and that would require more buttons for a rather clumsy result (try building a house of cards in Tabletop Simulator, for example).
Regardless, the game makes decent use of old and new mechanics to create a bunch of little puzzles with multiple solutions.

Audio is great, featuring an OST by the same amazing Ari Pulkkinen that did the music for the previous titles of the game.

Online multiplayer is good. Has a few quirks, but remains playable, and in my experience does not have any major issues. The only thing to mention here is that the levels are the same regardless of the number of the players, so playing together only opens new ways of completing puzzles and levels through cooperation.

On the obvious downside, the game is pretty short. That's a thing.
However, there's a thing that places it aside of other shorter-than-expected games - it has a level editor and Steam Workshop support.
And not just any level editor, but the same level editor that was used to make levels in the actual game - you can do anything that you see in the game with it. And publish it on workshop. And play it with people online.
So you could make a bunch of custom levels. Or modify the standard levels to make them harder (be that obstacles or puzzles). Or use scripting to just mess with things and make something that works completely differently.
There's an official wiki[frozenbyte.com] on the editor too.
Having seen many games, I think this is a very important thing long-term.

All things said, I consider this a worthy title for a collection,

reviewText:
Precision platforming with wonky, floaty, INCREDIBLY frustrating physics engine
Levels that are not designed well (in many, many cases it is very easy to fall down to instant death during the maneuver such as stomp, because maneuver moves your character in a huge step in a random direction).
Directional controls often change assigned directions in a middle of movement.

3D wasn't an improvement – levels are narrow, without any true freedom or camera control.

Play Trine 1 and 2, and watch 3 on youtube – you'll save yourself from a lot of frustration for which you'd have to pay your own money otherwise.

reviewText:
ESPRESSO SHOT REVIEWPlay between three different types of characters on the fly as you have fun doing some action puzzling.  Graphics are beautiful, levels are fun, and the puzzles are not overly intense.  Expect a short, but gratifying game that is easy to finish in a weekend.

PROS-	wow, super amazing 3D graphics with ultra details
-	fun levels that are well thought out
-	varying gameplay between the three characters
-    books with teeth


CONS-	the super amazing 3D graphics sort of ruin the old style of gameplay
-	no skills get upgraded
-	lack of replayability, it’s really short

THE FULL FRENCHED PRESSED CUP REVIEW
I had the pleasure of playing this game in alpha and finished all the levels a long time ago.  When I went back to the game after it was officially released, I found all my save files were removed and I’d have to play the game over from the beginning.  I half expected that, so I just backlogged playing the full game at that point.  Fast forward to mid 2016 and I finally got around to playing it over again.  The majority of the game was already finished when I played it last, so really I only got a few new levels and a few new side quests to complete after my replay.  All that said, it was a enjoyable game albeit rather short.

To be fair, I played Trine 2 and Trine 1 at the same time as when I was starting out on Trine 3.  There were pluses and minuses.  While I rather enjoyed the level action oriented design on Trine 3, I felt the puzzles themselves took a backseat.  Trine 1 honestly had the best puzzles of the bunch, with Trine 2 following behind that.  Part of the reason, I feel, is that the game no longer was in 2 planes, but had a 3rd plane of movement that often changed the way Trine 3 dealt with objects.  It sort of resembled Prince of Persia more than Trine and I think some puzzle design had to be simplified because of it.  Another reason might be because it moved along at a faster pace than the other Trine games, slow puzzling would off-set the momentum built into those levels.  You can’t go through a harrowing escape only to get stuck on a puzzle that takes extra time – or maybe I am wrong, I think Resident Evil has a fair amount of that with no issues.  In any case, the design of Trine 3 is more action, puzzle platforming with a emphasis on using the 3rd plane of movement.  Also, there is no skill leveling as before, making the skills you start with the same as the ones you end with.  Does that make it a bad game?  No.  Does it make it a better game? Also, no.  Is it a good game at all?  Yes.  And that is entirely because it’s still Trine and you still get that thought provoking gameplay where you can attack the situation at hand with three different characters that play very differently.

And that’s where I address gameplay.  You can switch between Amadeus, who is a cube conjuring-levitation expert magician ( mage, wizard, warlock, I am not sure of the proper term used in the game );  Pontius, a very powerful warrior who can float quite well on his shield as well as block/ground pound/ and divert things; and Zoya, a very agile thief who uses ropes to pull and move ringed objects.  I used an Xbox controller for gaming and found it very intuitive to use…except for Amadeus.  I thought it worked better using a mouse and keyboard for him.  Often, I’d be right in front of an object for him to levitate and not be able to get the object to comply with my controller.  Over and over again I would fail to grab the object with the blue “X” button highlighted, plus moving the object was substantially more difficult with a controller once I got it.  Playing Trine 2 was a LOT easier.  I’d use Amadeus the least amount if I could, but I felt the puzzles relied on him and Pontius substantially more than Zoya.   Once in a while, I’d use Zoya but only to get an elevator working or pull some gates up.  You *need* to use Amadeus and Pontius a great deal more often. So, I went through using my controller for Amadeus and it didn’t hinder me until the end levels where his slow reactions became a huge detriment.  I tried mouse and keyboard and while I could maneuver with him better, I was slower with the other characters.  So, back to the controller for me and finally finished the game.

Now, I’ve read some criticisms of the game being too short, bad camera angles, odd controls that are imprecise, etc.  Honestly, those are *all* solid complaints and I won’t try to defend them.  Yes, the game is rather short.  The studio simply did not have the funds to make it a full fledged Trine game.  I *did* have some weird camera angles, nothing game breaking, but yes somewhat annoying.  The controls are a bit slow when using Amadeus as noted, but perfectly fine for Pontius and Zoya. So, shortcomings aside, it is still a good game on it’s own merit.  I love the Trine games, and that alone gets them in the ballpark for me.  You’ve got the rope swinging, battle ground pounding, conjuring bits of fun that I enjoyed in Trine 1 and Trine 2.  That said, you won’t have the same feeling as you do in Trine 1 and 2.  Different games, don’t expect the same gameplay or puzzles.  You most likely will not get stuck for a bit as you do in Trine 1 and 2 where you use some extra brain cells to figure out what to do next.  For a short, fun action puzzler that looks AMAZING then Trine 3 is a nice game to finish in a weekend.  Plus, I think Amadeus has a wonderfully goofy walk that makes my 7 year old laugh when I try to walk like that.  7.5/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fantastic introduction to a new Trine game with incredible graphics and very well implemented 3D worlds, but one that feels very empty and desperate for more content to justify it’s price. If you’re a massive fan of Trine with a desperation to try out the brand new 3D features then absolutely, go ahead. The 3D is very well implemented and a joy to play, adding a brand new dimension (literally) to an already fantastic game. I genuinely can’t wait for the full release, but still feel like I could have waited without playing it in tiny increments like this. If you’re wanting a fully fledged or even content packed Early Access game, you may want to look elsewhere, at least for now.

Full review here![www.idiotbox.co.uk]

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I plan on updating my review when the game is out of Early Access

Where to start. I really enjoyed the first two Trine games with my friends. They are excellent co-op games.

The gameplay is similar to the first two Trine games aside from the new 3D elements. Instead of only going left and right you can now move towards and away from the screen. This takes some getting used to but it adds something interesting to the game.  The graphics look great. There is a lot of eye candy in this game. The music/sound effects are so so at the moment. The voice acting is great but most of the sound effects don't appear to be finished/polished.

At the moment there are not that many levels out but the devs for this game keep adding content often. More often then I was expecting. The developers are consistently responding to bug reports and listening to feedback. These guys deserve your money.

reviewText:
I loved the first two titles in the series, and I love the visuals of the third game, but gameplay-wise...it feels like an almost all-around downgrade to me right now. You can't grapple entire surfaces anymore, only specific spots on surfaces, can't move whole platforms with the wizard (not sure yet if blessing or curse), nor draw crates or beams, they are created when you press a button, etc. Right now the click-detection is seriously buggy, physics range from acceptable to horrendous, game-mechanics are communicated poorly (which is a big problem considering many of them are counter-intuitive) and the game is seriously unfinished. On top of all of that, the game suffers the typical shortfalls of a 3D platformer, such as impossible-to-gauge distances and random deaths from leaps of faith.

Could it be really good once finished? Absolutely, and I hope it will be. Would I recommend you buy it now? Absolutely not.

I will update my review in a while when the progress is a bit further along.


EDIT/UPDATE:

I just replayed the first levels (and the new levels they added), and they fixed many of the issues I had previously, and added cool new mechanics (new to Trine as a series) to the recently-added levels. I feel like now that there's over an hour of fun gameplay here, I can change my recommendation to yes"
date:
they're hard at work and it shows.

EDIT/UPDATE 2:
I can't believe they just released....the game is super-short and still suffers from many of the complaints I previously brought up. Can not recommend at full price."

reviewText:
I was quite sure to give a negative review but somehow I don't feel like it anymore.
I do not recommend Trine3 outside of a sale.
I do not recommend Trine3 for someone who has not played Trine1 and Trine2 before.
But I still recommend it as a game for itself.

Visuals:
The game looks great. But the ones before did as well. Exciting and complicated puzzles
should make you blend out the good looks. Intermissions, story moments etc. should get you
back into enjoying them. Sadly Trine3 lacks in the puzzle area. Worse, the great visuals come at a high performance cost. I don't run a perfect gaming system atm but a game like Trine should be able to run with high framerates on any modern computer. (I7, Quadro) Lowest quality, no vsync, reduced resolution and it still feels sluggish.
Takeaway:
- Keep the more flexible and even better looks. (Walking through the pages of a book etc.)
- Make sure the game runs fast enough for extensive puzzling.

Environment:
The engine allows for full 3d movement, the logic however, does not. Input is typically limited to two dimensions with mouse and keyboard. Using WASD and the mousewheel to control 3 dimensions is not a well trained method. It only works as a gimmick in some puzzles when you bring a box closer to the front or back.
Instead of real 3d puzzles Trine3 uses different slices of 2d. In Trine1 and Trine2 you make your way between left and right as well as up and down. Trine3 adds front to back traversal. But most puzzles are reduced to a 2d logic either by walking on the ground plane or by working on a single logical depth layer. Sometimes the logical dimensions are bent and twisted around the 3d environment. Walking a curved balcony still means walking backwards or forwards.
Takeaway:
- Keep the 3d environment as a technical base.
- Slice more strictly into 2d for puzzles, to reduce input back to 2d.

Puzzles:
Mostly disappointing. Most puzzles are not about Huh? Lets see. How can I solve this?".
Its more like "Urgh. Do I really have to make those jumps and move all those boxes?".
I was rarely amazed by how a puzzle could be solved. Most of them are straightforward. A few combinations with Zoyas ropes were interesting
date: but I would not see them on par with Amadeus planks and boxes from the former games. They are also less comfortable to experiment with
recommended: since the rigid body dynamics of planks and boxes are a lot easier to understand.\nIts understandable that the enviroment and selected skills make it hard to build great puzzles. But that is the challenge for a Trine game. Amadeus has been heavily reduced
hoursPlayed: most likely because controls would be too bothersome with all his flexibility from Trine1 and Trine2. But Zoyas rope trick are not making up for it enough. Mostly its "Tie this
voteText: pull here
helpfulPercent: tie that". There are many single character levels
votesHelpful:
which I see as a sign that the skills are not that well balanced and in combination make the quality of the puzzles drop.
Takeaway:
- Go for new skills and new combinations. Trine1 and Trine2 are already made.
- Support more variety/experimenting by using simpler to control and better to anticipate skills. Trine needs the "Wait! What if...?" moments.

Story and progress:
To me Trine was never about a great story. It was about great delivery. With that it is very hard to keep the quality up
votesTotal: because repeating things will make them taste shallow. But I am sure Trine3 was a good deal below its possibilities. With the first two games I never felt like "Oh. Thats where the kids are supposed to laugh
votesFunny: right?" Trine3 did not much to entertain me around the puzzles.\nThe grindable map is nice for backtracking
commentsCount: but backtracking and grinding Trine feels wrong to me. I prefer a more strict separation of story mode and puzzle mode / multiplayer. I do not see much replay value in finding a few pickups that I missed. The former games motivated me
column16: to be thorough because I wanted to buy upgrades. But I also felt like strictly progressing forward through a story. Trine3 lets me replay everything as much as I like. Even parts of a level. But I am neither driven to make progress nor do I care about the pickups. Except for when they stop me from entering another level. A required number of pickups and grinding reduces reduces the gratification from "getting past that spot
column17:
so I can move on".
Takeaway:
- Trine is not about the perfect story. Its about delivery and three characters.
- Some people want the linear experience. Some people want to grind puzzles alone or with friends. You should be able to support both."

reviewText:
My rating (out of 5 stars):
Trine 3: 3.75 stars
Trine 2: 5 stars
Trine 1: 4.5 stars
I had really high hopes for this third installment in the Trine series. And it delivered and kinda disappointed at the same time. Because the worlds are now 3D, the controls have changed to work with a 3D world instead of a 2D world. It takes some time getting used to the new controls. Controls are accurate and responsive. Graphics are fantastic. Music is great, but not as great as Trine 2 (and some of Trine 1's tracks).

What I Love: The 3D graphics, the 3D worlds and the ability to move in any direction. The ability to use with 3D TVs for an amazing 3D experience. Some fantastic new creativity in worlds and other characters you have to interact with (but also a negative-see below). Moving into the screen in 3D is a fun and exciting experience.  While they got the 3D nearly perfect, they didn't spend enough time developing a game better than Trine 2.

What I Hate: The single character levels where there are no checkpoints. If you fall, or slip into death by accident, you have to repeat the entire level from the beginning. It gets frustrating when you are inches from the end of a level. Some of the levels are not easy. While practice makes perfect, it's more frustrating than enjoyable. This game is also shorter than the first two games. Also what's missing is the character puzzles from Trine 2 which made it so amazing. It seems there is less creativity put into this game and more focus on getting the 3D right. Not a good tradeoff. I would have been happier with a 2D game with much better and properly developed game made better than Trine 2. Also, the music is not as good as the first two games.

reviewText:
Overall it's a beautiful game. There are few negative sides to the game.

The story is very short. It ends on a huge cliffhanger. The whole game up to the end can be considered as introduction to the story and where you expect it to really begin it ends. Very unfortunate.

Controls are a little bit different from previous parts and navigating in 3D is confusing at time. It can be a challenge to land where you panned to.

Enemies are weak though and can be ignored completely. It's a shame, because they added extra challenge in previous parts.

I would recommend the game to fans of the series. Though I can expect them to be disappointed with abrupt ending.

reviewText:
This is a beautifully animated, lovingly crafted game. None of these negative reviews can deny this. I loved every second of this game, as few as there were, and I can't say I wouldn't buy it again knowing what I know about the game.

The criticisms must be met with some agreement; the wizard loses out on some of his original feel without being able to pile up an absurd number of objects in the environment, of course, and the thief does feel a bit more simple as far as aiming goes, but don't let that fool you into thinking this game is a cop out from the developers.

The true fault of the game is that Frozenbyte, a young, ambitious studio, bit off more than they could chew with the third dimension. Once again, the studio did amazingly well in the visual department, and have a good framework for an amazing game...

But they ran out of money, so the game's short. It took me six and a half hours to beat this game with some extra work put in for some collectibles. Take that how you will: they cut off the story, so it doesn't seem hasty or rushed; they just have about 10-12 more levels to make.

I highly recommend that Trine lovers do buy this game, albeit wait for a sale maybe. Frozenbyte hasn't made a cash grab, and it hasn't abandoned their players; don't abandon them. Please. Not yet.

reviewText:
First Trine was awesome, second Trine was great. In third Trine they just needed to keep all accomplishments from previous parts and add some new story. But developers decide to rework all.
They add useless 3D enviroment, which made controlling characters too ambiguous and confusing.
Characters now dont have any skills. Knight can just hit and run. Thief can just shoot and grapple. Wizard is only who use more then 2 buttons: he still can create and levitate crate, but thats all of his skills.
It follows that new levels are very simple. You just running through without any hesitation.
But the worst is the system of unlocking new levels. Now you need to collect orange pyramids to move forward the story. And sometimes you must to complete the most boring side levels cause you dont have enough of pyramids.

Trine 3 is the spitting in the face of all fans of previous Trines.
