reviewText:
Early Access Review

I imagine that the thought process behind developing this game went something like this:

- Hey Johan! (i assume that there is at least one person name Johan there, since the developers are from Finland) We've made two amazing and beautiful platformers with puzzles that everyone loved but i still feel that there is something missing from my life. I feel like we can do more! I feel like we should have at least one game in our series that is going to ruin everything we done previously and provoke rage and hatred, so then we could compete with EA and Ubisoft and consider ourselves real gaming studio! What do you think?

- I agree completely Olaf (its probably not a Finnish name but i am not that familiar with their naming practices unfortunately). What did you have in mind?

- Well i thought that we could make it 3d this time, so it would completely ruin perspective so people wouldn't understand where the game world ends and background scenery begins and constantly fall to their death's or get stuck! We would also have to make our backgrounds less beautiful and static than they were previously, because our engine and players systems won't be able to handle it in 3d!

- I like the way you think Johan! Might i also suggest removing all wooden surfaces and replace them with strategically placed hoops, so the thief would play more like Lara Croft in those weird platformer spin-offs that barely anyone likes? Also lets screw with camera angles so it wouldn't follow player everywhere and make it even more frustrating to play?

- Yes! Yes! Lets also remove wizard mechanics, so he wouldn't have to draw stuff and just cast it with one button! It will ruin the immersion and yet another neat feature that people loved! Also it will be much harder to place items in 3d since you would have to move them in one more axis!

- And we will do everything in early access, so there would be a lot of bugs, like disappearing sounds, music and cursor, broken ragdoll animations and graphical glitches!

- Huzzah!

Then they hugged and celebrated, and a lot of pickled herring was consumed that day.

Thus the Trine 3 was born.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Its all true though and i did like previous games. It just shows what can ****king with a good concept lead to. Because of 2d they could've used amazing, animated and almost alive backgrounds, which made it look like you were playing an interactive book or something. Now its just another 3d platformer.

I've got both of those arcade Lara Croft games and i've played them a lot - its exactly like that now. In fact thief now uses her whip the same way Lara uses her zip line.

It doesn't mean that the game is bad now but i am not a huge fan of changing something for the sake of change. The game did not improve and instead just lost something special in the transition. At the very least i can honestly say that backgrounds now look worse, i assume because they couldn't make them as bright, as polished and animated, since they had to make a lot more of them.

Not everything is better in 3d, except:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pOXStLCZrPM

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Also - i'd like to thank the developers for having a sense of humor and answering to this review and my concerns politely :)

I might have been wrong about Finnish names but at least we all can agree that pickled herring in red wine sauce is amazing!

reviewText: Sometimes Yes and No on steam reviews is not enough! Yes, I would recommend, but at the same time that they killed the game in some points. They ♥♥♥♥ing removed ability tree, so there is no perspective of getting stronger, and no cool skills anymore (I really missed the gravity arrows and the multiple boxes). The other thing that killed the game, is the story, VERY short, and ends literally in the middle of it, out of nowhere. I'm very sad, the game had everything to be phenomenal, the 3D it is confusing at the start, but very immersive, the soundtrack is awesome as always, and the graphics are stunning, but they ♥♥♥♥ed up what should be a really great game.\nIt's with a heavy heart that I'm giving the game a negative review, so the Developers can see that the game need some upgrades. If they launch a free dlc with skills and more story, I will change this review with no time.

reviewText:
While Trine 1 and Trine 2 are exceptionally good I cannot say the same for Trine 3.

It was somewhat fun, but I was waiting the entire game to get skills (Ice arrow, Fire arrow, Mage stuff) or at lease new mechanics. The game mechanics were always the same and overly simple.

I finished the game in ~5 hours and it was enough to find a lot of bugs. What annoyed me the most were the glitch graphics that made my entire machine freeze for some seconds constantly, I had to tune down the graphics.

The ending was really annoying as well, it didn't end! This feeling is really annoying, I am most likely never going to buy any DLC to see the ending, no way... That was ridiculous. I will only play if they release a DLC for free apologizing.

I'm sorry to any team member that is reading this, but I feel really frustrated and I hope you understand. The game has potential, it might have been just way too soon to release.

reviewText:
While I enjoyed Trine and Trine 2 to a great extend, I cannot recommend the third installment of the series.
I simply can't imagine how anyone would have thought a transition into a more 3 dimensional world would do the gameplay any good. Even though the difficulty of the game is anything but hardcore, it gets so frustrating to repeatedly miss jump after jump, just because there is no indicator, where you might be landing. And while jumping is the most basic action you will perform every few seconds during the game, it is even more anoying to try and place boxes, swing on ropes, shoot arrows oder pull objects to a specific location because it's just hit and miss all the time.

And what's even more frustrating are those damned pyramids, which you have to collect, since you need a certain amount of them to unlock levels in the game. But since those things are sometimes hidden in places like boxes without any indication of them beeing in there, it results in you flailing wildly while jumping through the stages in basicaly uncontrolable patterns just so you don't have to play a level again because you missed one of them.


Seriously though: Even with all the mixed and bad reviews I still wanted Trine 3 to be good, just because I adored the first two installments. Those were genuinely great platformers. Do yourself a favor and just buy and play those two, instead of wasting your money on this one.

reviewText:
Buy this, but only at a major discount.

A good game, cut short by production costs or whatever. Really, the game ends just when you think you've finished chapter 1.

Also, it's very different from the previous two.  It's much more a 3D platformer, where depth has a meaning. That's both good and bad. It's good because it's more interesting, but sometimes it's just annoying, since you can't move the camera.

This one is also prettier than the first two, which were also very pretty themselves. On the other hand, the puzzles are very very easy. Unlike the first two games where you sometimes (not very often) had to think.

reviewText:
A hesitant recommendation. Trine 3 has fewer levels available and fewer abilities compared to Trine 2. It has a significantly higher amount of bugs that need to be worked out. Additionally, the story is not fully resolved at the end of the game. Either DLC is planned or Trine 4 will conclude it. For a fully released game, it sure played like an Early Access title.

The game is good overall, but the other ones are likely better. Extremely buggy, high amounts of physics issues and net code synching issues when it comes to the achievments. If I was a fan of the series I would be highly disappointed.

Pros: Fun puzzle game, ability to switch between characters in a new game mode
Cons: Bugs in synching collectibles in multiplayer vs singleplayer, physics engine is buggy, incomplete story to sell DLC or a sequel. Released incomplete and in a poor state

GOOD:
+++ it takes a bit of effort to get used to the new 3D gameplay, but the overall result is AMAZING!
The way the camera follows you as the action evolves really makes you fell part of the story.
Kudos to the developers for taking such an ambitious step!

BAD:
--- It takes about 8 hours to complete, which is not as bad as many people stated for about 12£...but it really does fell like the story has been cut short.
--- The game is not that challenging...Trine 2 in comparison was much more difficult and rewarding in this sense.

Overall I recommend this game to any fan of the series (and of platforms/adventure games in general) and I'm really looking forward to the next chapter!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
It's game which shouldn't have left early access in my opinion, its unfinished. The story is half a story, I was amazed when it finished how it did, as early as it did.

I sincerely struggle to believe that the team which developed this would place it alongside Trine or Trine 2 in terms of quality, in terms of strength of puzzles, charm, the flexibility which you have in tackling puzzles, level design, length of game and general overall completeness of the product. It isn't there.

Trine 1 & 2 are classics, on any system. Two of the best games ever made. Trine 3 takes what made the previous games and strips the game back to almost barebones. Amongst the changes are that Amadeus can't cast planks at all or multiple crates or cage enemies, Pontius' hammer / magnetic shield is gone, Zoya's grav / fire / freeze arrows and multiple arrows are gone, the rope swing also seems to have been nerfed meaning less scope for acrobatics - its changes like that in my opinion which limit the puzzles and overall fun of the game. The puzzles are weak and the new 3D engine is more psuedo 3D in my eyes. The new ability which Zoya has to attach rope to rope points works well, the boss fights are a marked improvement but it isn't enough.

Its the weakest game in the series by far from a developer which should know better. Such a let down.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I think the internet really was too harsh on this one. Savadgely attacking devs who misjudged the cost/time involved in making large changes to their game wasn't deserved. I for one liked most of the changes, the new levels were nice if different than what I was expecting. I think the biggest problem here was unmanaged expectations and early access.

Gamers loved Trine and Trine 2 and I'm positive 90+% of them just wanted what was essentially Trine 2: More Levels. I don't think it was made clear early enough the departures being attempted and how much it was likely to be difficult.  Trine devs should have been a bit more upfront about their difficulties, people understand if told in advance.

I think the other problem was early access and taking people's money before the game was ready. I almost never buy early access because I don't like unfinished products. I think people need to realize that just like Kickstarter, if you pay for something unfinished you are gambling a bit on how it will end up.

All that said, I do hope Frozenbyte continue making cool platformers like Trine. It would be a shame to lose one of the last devs making such games. It is clear to me there was a brilliant game being made here, it just needed more time and money to be made. They just ran out.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about Frozenbyte's jump to a 3D environment. On one hand, I appreciate when a game developer tries something new and ultra-ambitious. On the other hand, I loved the aesthetic and gameplay of Trine 1 and 2, so I sort of feel like why fix what wasn't broken.
This game is beautiful, absolutely beautiful. There were more than a few moments where I paused and appreciated the artwork. But there were even more occasions where the 3D movement made puzzles confusing or frustrating, and that's not to mention the occasional clunky/glitchy 3D behavior (Zoya's swinging in particular). None of these things made the game unplayable, they just took me out of the moment.
The most startling aspect of the game is the 'cliffhanger,' where you are made to think they are just about to continue their quest, but then the credits start rolling. Actually, I wouldn't even mind the cliffhanger, if I knew they were continuing the story. But I've read, because of overly negative feedback, they are questioning whether or not they should. I really don't think that's fair, though, and I strongly feel that they (or anyone in their position) should finish what you've started.
It was, in the end, a fun game. Not the best in the series, but still fun. I would recommend it, especially if doing so meant they would finish the darn story.

reviewText:
Do not buy this game. Very disappointing sequel to an otherwise excellent franchise. Trine 3 attempts to a third dimension to a 2D platformer, which is so poorly implemented as to make the game frustratingly unplayable. The difficulty of the game is not in the intricacy of the puzzles, or clever level layout, but rather through gimicky, flimsy controls which leads to monotonous repitition.

- Previously it was possibly to aim the assassin's arrow because the environment only had two dimensions, now the game will automatically select a target based roughly on the character's heading.

- The same problem happens with the wizard, where you cannot tell which object is going to be affected by the levitation power until you press the button. You can no longer select objects with a cursor, instead game selects whatever arbitrary object is nearby to manipulate, or require you to toggle between multiple selectable objects if more than one exists on screen at a time. Once selected, manipulating objects in 3D space is ludicrously difficult, especially with a gamepad.

- Many obstacles need to be solved by placing objects ot jumping into" the screen (along the Z axis)
date: but without depth cues this is mostly just random guesswork.\n\n- When characters die a blue ghost avatar floats to a random location in the world. The character is resurrected by standing in or near the blue avatar for some time. Sometimes this is in an impossible to reach location (eg. a location requiring the assassin
hoursPlayed: or in the middle of an infinitely spawning battle (eg. requiring the knight
voteText: who is dead). Invariably this means forcibly killing the remaining characters and rewinding the game to a previous checkpoint
helpfulPercent: which are far and few between. In the earlier versions of the game
votesHelpful: characters would be resurrected immediately when passing a checkpoint."

reviewText:
Ok, so I'm a mad keen fan of Trine 1 and Trine 2, was Trine 3 what I expected.... NO.  Is it a bad game?  Not necessarily.

Probably the biggest fans of this game will be people who never played 1 & 2 and come with no preconcieved ideas.  The game is beautifully executed in the graphics department and fun so two big ticks there.

The let downs are in the gameplay specifically the lack of ability to move the camera, massive oversight for a 3D game, and I mean MASSIVE.

Other detractors are the lack of character development and loss of skills from earlier Trine games.

Pluses are, it's beautiful, new ways to solve puzzles and it's a noticeably different experience.  Not going to comment on length of game because it's adequate.  I mean I completed Tomb Raider in like 15 hrs and that cost me $70 at the time.

In short for me it's a solid 8/10 game.  Not brilliant but certainly good, a few tweaks such as being able to move the camera and a little more explanation on some of the abilities of the characters would have helped.

Full price, probably worth it, on sale, definitely get it.

I'm really sad to say I don't recommend it. I am a fan of the series, I played the first and the second trine, and i bought immediately the game in april when it was still in early access, with no doubts, but I was wrong.
But let's understand why.
In the first trine I loved the story, the graphics, the locations, the characters and their weapons, and the chests where you could find collectible items that improved your mana/health for example, the levelling, because the game became harder and you became stronger and I reached to build up to 6 boxes, to cut it short, it was perfect.
The second trine had too a great story, great graphics and locations, the characters that i loved to play again, I appreciated the levelling, the weapons, but the items disappeared, and the floating boxes for the wizard disappeared too, and the chests where I hoped to find the items contained just poems and that really disappointed me, but at least the poems told you about the story, so still, it was a good game.
But trine 3... during the early access I played the tutorials, the challenges and the first chapters wondering why I wasn't leveling up, why there weren't weapons, but I told myself the game was incomplete, and waited.

reviewText:
I actually think the $20 was worth it. Considering the effort they went through to create such gorgeous scenery, cinematics and 3D platforming (I never had problems with jumps btw), I'm only saddened by them not completing it because of financial limitations.

Also, if you read their forums, they're not going to release DLCs to sell.

They were literally chopped at their knees from lack of funding, but it resulted in a gorgeous game with a brilliant idea -- but it had to come to an end. I believe that even if they were able to pay for all the bills, people would still come with complaints. No game is perfect, but I'm glad Frozenbyte decided not to rip us off and at least give us an open ending to hope for more to come.

reviewText:
I do recommend this game, but not to everybody, as there are people that will find its faults weigh heavier than the fun of this game.

First, I admit to have played the previous two installments and was especially enchanted by the looks of part two. When I heard the announcement of the game developers to shift from a 2D to a 3D style sidescrolling puzzle-platformer, I was very eager for the inital reviews, and, to put it mildly, was shocked. The gameplay was said to render the game barely playable, and bugs would appear at any corner. So I waited for some time, and after only half a year the game was featured in a pretty cheap bundle, so this was the opportunity to pick it up and get my personal opinion. And boy, do I regret not having bought the game sooner (even though I probably woudn't have had the time to play it, just to make sales look nicer for what is in my opinion a very talented game development studio).

Yes, the new 3D style has a couple of downfalls, as you will misjudge some jumps or opponent locations. But seriously, I couldn't care less, because the art design and the music make more than up for it and are essentially the reason why you sit in awe in front of the game, finding it hard to believe this isn't in a gallery.  In comparison to the previous two games, the story ends on a cliffhanger, probably due to budget shortages. There are some nice and small bonus levels.  The characters have lost a couple of abilities, and there is no skill tree anymore (as rudimentary as that used to be). Honestly, Trine never felt like an RPG to begin with, so the loss of a couple of features isn't that hard on me. Still, I can see why fans might have felt a little let-down and disappointed at the initial release.

Overall, this is what you can expect from Trine 3: Beautiful graphics and art design, a good tune whenever you need one, and admittedly not that hard puzzles. However, if you're one quick to be frustrated by missing a jump or can't stand navigating levitating boxes around, better keep your distance: You can have a look at Trine 2 if you want to admire similar artwork, and if you find yourself wanting more of the same, you can always come back. I sure hope Frozenbyte will not take the harsher criticism towards the game to heart and continue their great work. 2D, 2.5D or 3D? Doesn't really matter to me.

reviewText:
It's game which shouldn't have left early access in my opinion, its unfinished. The story is half a story, I was amazed when it finished how it did, as early as it did.

I sincerely struggle to believe that the team which developed this would place it alongside Trine or Trine 2 in terms of quality, in terms of strength of puzzles, charm, the flexibility which you have in tackling puzzles, level design, length of game and general overall completeness of the product. It isn't there.

Trine 1 & 2 are classics, on any system. Two of the best games ever made. Trine 3 takes what made the previous games and strips the game back to almost barebones. Amongst the changes are that Amadeus can't cast planks at all or multiple crates or cage enemies, Pontius' hammer / magnetic shield is gone, Zoya's grav / fire / freeze arrows and multiple arrows are gone, the rope swing also seems to have been nerfed meaning less scope for acrobatics - its changes like that in my opinion which limit the puzzles and overall fun of the game. The puzzles are weak and the new 3D engine is more psuedo 3D in my eyes. The new ability which Zoya has to attach rope to rope points works well, the boss fights are a marked improvement but it isn't enough.

Its the weakest game in the series by far from a developer which should know better. Such a let down.

reviewText:
Here's my opinion on the points reviews tend to hit on:

3D CONTROLS?
I found the controls incredibly smooth! Zoya's rope is easy to manipulate, Pontius is easy as always to control. The only awkard part is controlling boxes with amadeus (two sticks are used), but any awkwardness included is the kind that's fun to play with. I personally had no trouble jumping on platforms.

POWERS
While the characters have no unlockable powers, they have been given other abilities. All characters can wall jump and grab ledges now. Pontius can still charge and use his sheild as a glider. He can also do a ground pound, which is pretty entertaining. Zoya has no special arrows, but her rope is AMAZING in this game. It can be used to tie stuff together and has actual rope physics now (ie can be wrapped around pillars, etc.). Amadeus got shorted by being given only one box to summon. He can pound it into the ground, however, making him able to fight enemies off.
I'm actually a fan of less powers, the 3D controls already complicate the controls , so I think it was a good move simplify things.

STORY
I was bummed about how the story gets cut off in the middle, but the game does leave you with a cliffhanger to wrap things up.

SHORT GAME
it's short, but it was the best 3-some hours of Trine I've played. It's pretty clear Frozenbyte went for quality rather than quantity. Every screen I saw there were new 3D models being used. There are some side challenges included with the main game.

DLC
I seriously doubt Frozenbyte is plotting some DLC scheme given the nature of the company. If they really wanted to rip people off, they would release DLC a few months after the first half. I would not mind buying the sequal if they decide to make it.

MAGICAL
yes, this game will make you feel like you are in a storybook, hands down. Every level is different from the last unlike the previous Trine games. There is even a level where the rendering changes to make you feel like you are in another world.

FINAL OPINION: Get this game! Its worth at least $10 despite the shortness.

reviewText:
Ok, so I'm a mad keen fan of Trine 1 and Trine 2, was Trine 3 what I expected.... NO.  Is it a bad game?  Not necessarily.

Probably the biggest fans of this game will be people who never played 1 & 2 and come with no preconcieved ideas.  The game is beautifully executed in the graphics department and fun so two big ticks there.

The let downs are in the gameplay specifically the lack of ability to move the camera, massive oversight for a 3D game, and I mean MASSIVE.

Other detractors are the lack of character development and loss of skills from earlier Trine games.

Pluses are, it's beautiful, new ways to solve puzzles and it's a noticeably different experience.  Not going to comment on length of game because it's adequate.  I mean I completed Tomb Raider in like 15 hrs and that cost me $70 at the time.

In short for me it's a solid 8/10 game.  Not brilliant but certainly good, a few tweaks such as being able to move the camera and a little more explanation on some of the abilities of the characters would have helped.

Full price, probably worth it, on sale, definitely get it.

reviewText:
Trine 3 is an interesting addition to the series.  The transition from 2D to 3D is actually handled reasonably well, and I had a good time playing through with different mechanics from the Trine 1+2 platforming.  Fortunately, the game retains Trine's lush visuals, so it's still a treat to look at, and the newer mechanics made possible by the move to 3D are fun (though I missed the more fluid rope-swinging that Zoya was capable of in Trine 1+2).

The transition to 3D is helped out somewhat by the level design, which for the most part allows you to play individual setpieces as if they were still a 2D puzzle.  It's true that sometimes player positioning becomes an issue, and occasionally you'll end up misjudging where you are in relation to where you're jumping, but overall I didn't have any problems with it really.  I did have a few unintentional deaths due to my character not being where I thought she was, but since death is only a minor inconvenience in the game, it never bothered me.

Character abilities are restricted compared to previous Trine games, to account for the increased complexity of dealing with them in a 3D environment, but it's nice that the characters start out with all of their abilities intact.  The trineangles" you collect in Trine 3 no longer count towards character upgrades

reviewText:
I do recommend this game, but not to everybody, as there are people that will find its faults weigh heavier than the fun of this game.

First, I admit to have played the previous two installments and was especially enchanted by the looks of part two. When I heard the announcement of the game developers to shift from a 2D to a 3D style sidescrolling puzzle-platformer, I was very eager for the inital reviews, and, to put it mildly, was shocked. The gameplay was said to render the game barely playable, and bugs would appear at any corner. So I waited for some time, and after only half a year the game was featured in a pretty cheap bundle, so this was the opportunity to pick it up and get my personal opinion. And boy, do I regret not having bought the game sooner (even though I probably woudn't have had the time to play it, just to make sales look nicer for what is in my opinion a very talented game development studio).

Yes, the new 3D style has a couple of downfalls, as you will misjudge some jumps or opponent locations. But seriously, I couldn't care less, because the art design and the music make more than up for it and are essentially the reason why you sit in awe in front of the game, finding it hard to believe this isn't in a gallery.  In comparison to the previous two games, the story ends on a cliffhanger, probably due to budget shortages. There are some nice and small bonus levels.  The characters have lost a couple of abilities, and there is no skill tree anymore (as rudimentary as that used to be). Honestly, Trine never felt like an RPG to begin with, so the loss of a couple of features isn't that hard on me. Still, I can see why fans might have felt a little let-down and disappointed at the initial release.

Overall, this is what you can expect from Trine 3: Beautiful graphics and art design, a good tune whenever you need one, and admittedly not that hard puzzles. However, if you're one quick to be frustrated by missing a jump or can't stand navigating levitating boxes around, better keep your distance: You can have a look at Trine 2 if you want to admire similar artwork, and if you find yourself wanting more of the same, you can always come back. I sure hope Frozenbyte will not take the harsher criticism towards the game to heart and continue their great work. 2D, 2.5D or 3D? Doesn't really matter to me.

reviewText:
Positives
--------------------
-Beautiful graphics
-Fun gameplay
-Intuitive puzzles
-Stellar in 3D and one of the few games that natively supports 3D

Negatives
------------------
-Pretty short, could probably beat it in a few hours
-Missing old character abilities

Overall Trine 3 is a short but amazing journey. The switch to making the gameplay in three dimensions actually was well done in my opinion, although many seem to disagree. I've played all of the Trine games just because they natively support 3D and the graphics are always beautiful. I would say it's definitely worth playing, especially if you buy it during a steam sale.

reviewText:
I actually think the $20 was worth it. Considering the effort they went through to create such gorgeous scenery, cinematics and 3D platforming (I never had problems with jumps btw), I'm only saddened by them not completing it because of financial limitations.

Also, if you read their forums, they're not going to release DLCs to sell.

They were literally chopped at their knees from lack of funding, but it resulted in a gorgeous game with a brilliant idea -- but it had to come to an end. I believe that even if they were able to pay for all the bills, people would still come with complaints. No game is perfect, but I'm glad Frozenbyte decided not to rip us off and at least give us an open ending to hope for more to come.

reviewText:
The Trine Trilogy is real eyecandy and nice story telling. New to Trine 3 is that you wont be able to advance your character - it has all its skills from the beginning. You start at chapter 1 and depending on how many Pyramids you collect on your way thourgh the chapter the more side chapters you are able to play. That said, its up to you if you go straight for the main chapters or take a detour. Though I cant say, if they are optional or if you have to do them to make it to the final chapter, as I do the optional chapters first. The thing is, every chapter requires a certain amount of collected pyramids and if you dont have them you have to collect them in previous chapters - its a bit of like collecting stars in super mario bros to get the extra level, bit old school, but fine.

A big pro is that it is playable in coop

Trine 3 added the third dimension - most of the time it is not that much of an issue. The real downer is, that you cant adjust the camera, so some things are hard to tell where they are in depth or are hidden from you, because you have not the right angle to spot them.

The 3D is also the reason, why I play it with a pad - keyboard is very bit painful IMHO for 3D. But my pad is a 8 key, 2-axis pad and it gets real difficult to play the mage with that, as you cant lever stuff as you are supposed to do, so I probably need to upgrade my pad for such kind of games.

The level design is beatiful, while a tad on the short side - after a half day, I'm almost through with most pyramids collected.

Despite getting used to 3D the game has some quality issue in terms of bugs. Especially when it comes to coop play. Like that the other player cant move or my screen goes black when another player joins. In classic mode, when I die I cant switch character and have to wait until I get revived - my colleque is able to switch to another character and revive the fallen character. Rather seldom some scripted events fail.

Considering the gameplay I would buy it again, but I wish some patches get out to make it less frustrating from time to time...

reviewText:
Trine 3 was a really big let-down for me.  Trine 1 and 2 were amazing and are probably in my top 10 coop games, but 3 is just a nightmare of glitchy physics, long loading times and hard-to-control characters.

Gone is any purpose for collecting all the tokens/experience/trinangles to improve your character and revisit old worlds with new abilities, gone are half the abilities the characters had - including my favourite, being able to make surfboards with Amadeus - replaced with glitchy and hard-to-use abilities that completely crap themselves if you play over a network.

Speaking of glitchy, you'll be lucky if you don't have to restart a level because of dumb things like characters being invisible for the whole level, or boucy boxes floating up into the sky.

Do I still recommend playing?  Yes.   There aren't enough decent coop games out there, and this one is more than 0 amounts of fun.  But I'll be going back to Trine 2 once I finish 3.

(Also, is it just me, or does the narrator sound drunk?)

reviewText:
Honnestly I loved this game,

I am a big Trine fan and own all the Trine games and love how these developers are not afraid to try something new.
While i like the 2D Trine games a lot, I enjoyed this 3D gameplay version a lot as well.

Once I started playing I couldn't stop, the story pulled me in and got me excited for the next chapter. This is why i think the story felt a little short. I kept loosing track of time and continued completing chapters because I wanted to know the next part of the story.

The characters felt familliar but slightly different, from the new use of Zoya's rope to the charging and slamming of Pontius. The new game features got me wanting more.

Finally the artstyle was breathtaking. Like the 2D games Trine 3 has delivered a colourful environment that felt alive. From start to finish it felt polished and complete, even with some different artstyles throughout the game.

Short Summary;
If you like big games with a lot of replayability i would not reccomend this game but rather a bigger multiplayer game. But if you want to get pulled into a story with an amazing artstyle, and enjoy some casual game time with some friends through an enjoyable co-op game. Then this is a great game for you!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Trine3(D).

If it wasn't called Trine, I'm sure reviews would be way more positve. The negative reviews seem more based on it being different to Trine1&2. This is really not a bad game at all. Hear me through...

Firstly, play it with an Xbox controller if you have one. Game plays really well with it. The 3D concept is not too hard at all, is a nice twist on the previous incarnations (you can see they worked really hard to take the game to new heights, even if it misses a lot of the playability of the first two). I actually found the game too easy if anything.

Pros: Graphics A++++, mostly good fun. Level editor. It's a cheap game (esp on sale).

Cons: A little short (5-6 hours), missing level up RPG with character powers. Puzzles not up to T1/T2 (prob because characters are missing skills). Combat very simplistic. That ending?!

reviewText:
Certainly the weakest part in the series by far. Moving it to 3D didn't really work out at all -- I was constantly fighting the 3D because I was never sure where things were, and I haven't even gotten anywhere in the combat challenge for Amadeus.

Also, they cut off the story abruptly, then added filler material. The combat challenges in particular are annoying; I believe those are the only levels that I haven't done (yet?).

As for the characters -- they didn't just forget all their skills like they did in Trine 2 -- this time around, they never gained skills either. A positive aspect, in some way, is that all puzzles are trivial.

The story itself -- I didn't like it. Not the abrupt ending but the actual content. I never pictured the three as *really* wanting to get rid of the Trine, so the whole thing felt contrived throughout

Now, unfortunately, you can only vote yes" and "no" -- there is no middle ground. The game is weak compared to its predecessors
recommended: but it's not "bad". So I still give it "yes"
hoursPlayed: but if you haven't played the other two: start with those. They are far better.\n"

reviewText:
I've played for an hour and a half so far and I've enjoyed most of my time with the game. It's still the same kind of fun I've had playing Trine 2 with some friends and the game does feel open and more lenient than the previous title. Yes, there has been a lot of changes and not all may be for the better but the game feels new and fresh while keeping the core essence of a Trine game.

What I've found so far:
* The game looks great with varied and creative environments!
* The controls work well enough, they take some getting used to but that's OK.
* The camera IS annoying sometimes and doesn't scroll as far as it should.
* There are some glitches and the game doesn't feel quite as polished as Trine 2 did but I've had no major issues so far.

If you've played Trine 2 and enjoyed it, I think you should pick up this one too. It is a bit unpolished, the story is supposedly cut short and there are some things to be annoyed about but if you can look past that and approach the game with an open mind (and even better, get some friends to join) it's a fun game. Buy it on a sale I suppose.

reviewText:
Trine 3 was a really big let-down for me.  Trine 1 and 2 were amazing and are probably in my top 10 coop games, but 3 is just a nightmare of glitchy physics, long loading times and hard-to-control characters.

Gone is any purpose for collecting all the tokens/experience/trinangles to improve your character and revisit old worlds with new abilities, gone are half the abilities the characters had - including my favourite, being able to make surfboards with Amadeus - replaced with glitchy and hard-to-use abilities that completely crap themselves if you play over a network.

Speaking of glitchy, you'll be lucky if you don't have to restart a level because of dumb things like characters being invisible for the whole level, or boucy boxes floating up into the sky.

Do I still recommend playing?  Yes.   There aren't enough decent coop games out there, and this one is more than 0 amounts of fun.  But I'll be going back to Trine 2 once I finish 3.

(Also, is it just me, or does the narrator sound drunk?)

reviewText:
Great, as long as you weren't expecting a complete game, it ends rather abruptly.

I actually enjoyed the changed from 2D to 3D, it was artfully done. As always, the Trine games are beutiful masterpieces and with a glorious sound track.

However, compared to the first games, this third is severly lacking. Aside from the fact it just stops. there is no character development at all, and there are none of the traits from Trine 2, eg fire arrows, ice arrows, talents, hammers. Hell, there isn't even a frigging plank. Your wizard is now a one box wonder.

I didn't really like the side levels either, where you are restricted to a single character. For building an entire series on how 3 different characters can solve any puzzle, these side levels are just crap filler. Why didn't you finish the main game instead of wasting time on this pap?

Hopefully Frozen Byte get their acts together and deliver something substantial in future. I'm not overly impressed with Shadwen even though I love stealth games as a rule.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
TL;DR: The game is boring, and multiplayer is buggy but it looks nice.

This game has some serious issues, both technical and design oriented. After playing Trine 2 with friends and loving it, we decided to try out Trine 3.

I got a bad feeling as soon as I learned there was no skill system, and from there the game got worse. In the first mission, we experienced a bug where only the host could see the animation of a puzzle, making me and my other friend useless in it. (Un)fortunately, it seems that all 3 characters now can do essentially the same things, making the puzzle possible even though only one person could interact with it. The addition of a third dimension (while adding depth to gameplay in some ways) mostly just made the controls a mess.

The only positive thing I can say about this game is that if you liked the Trine series for the aesthetic, you will enjoy this game as it improves upon the graphics of the previous installments. However, if you liked Trine for the mayhem and fun that came from playing with your friends, it probably isn't worth a buy.

I know that I only have around an hour of this game on record, and I think that that's an important thing to note when reading this review.Maybe I judged this game too quickly, but I'm not going to waste anymore time on a buggy, mechanicly void platformer.

reviewText:
Trine 3 is an experimentation that didn't really work out well from the change from side scrolling to 3d for the trine series

pros
- music is great, same storybook fantasy feel
- The graphics are nice but honestly think they looked better in trine 2

cons
- The game developers ran out of money basically so yeah the story doesn't even end properly as the adventures find one piece of the item they need and the game ends there. You don't even fight the main antagonist so you can basically assume about 1/2 to 1/3 of the game is missing.  So it's essentially a 6 hour game.
- I think they did an ok job with the controls considering, but you die ALOT to falling off things because it's hard to judge depth in a 3D game with a fixed camera, you have infinite resses basically unless all your party dies so it's really pretty hard to even fail this game.
- There also seems to be far less puzzle solving than in previous games and much easier, a few times I literally said is that it" when you put 3 boxes on 3 tiles to open a door.
_ The characters have been stripped down of abilities
